deck_excerpt: Force out a grindgame with Superdreadnought Super Dora and win in a battle of attrition with Fortress - all backed by an arsenal of purple cards!
deck_description:
A deck specifically made for the "Common Charity" format that is officially supported by Konami. This format only uses cards that come in the common rarity.
Here is a bit of a simpler deck explanation as opposed to my 2000 word+ articles. I'm gonna pump out quite a bit of Common Charity guides in the near future for the sake of this young and exciting format! Inspired by the surprisingly successful Trap Machina list that topped PAK's LCS Tourney, Machina Train Control copies that strategy, geared for Common Charity! Losing the resource/boardwipe loop that Machina is famous (Machina Citadel) and its primary searcher (Machina Redeployment) this deck is focused lesser on a Machina strategy but more towards trains. Control the board with Traps and Trains, and grind your opponent out in a resource war! Designed to turbo out its nigh invincible boss monster Number 81, Superdreadnought Rail Cannon Super Dora, the strategy of this deck is a "protect the castle" strategy - Sit on a unaffected high attack monster while backed with trap cards. Even if Super Dora is taken out, this deck easily can make it again, especially with access to its fieldspell, Revolving Switchyard. The traps used in this deck feature some of the most ridiculous floodgates in the game, completely shutting down opponent's plays while your plays are unhindered. Gozen Match shuts down most "meta" Common Charity decks like Tenyi and Lunalight. Imperial Order and Anti-Spell Fragrance prevent spell cards from being used. Machina Overdrive turns any machine into Machina Fortress, a strong boss monster on its own right. Since this deck features many high level machine monsters, Fortress is easily summonable from the hand or GY. Gearframe and Unclaspare also give access to Fortress, since they both foolish burial Fortress to the GY. In the grindgame, Fortress almost always trades more often in your favour, due to it's effects when destroyed by battle or targeted by card effect. In the grind game, Time Thief Redoer is KING in Common Charity, and he can be made easily with Machine Gearframe + Machine Unclaspare. Other rank 4 options are available, depending on the situation. The trap cards Crackdown, Torrential Tribute, Judgment and Strike are chosen since they are the highest impact cards that trade positively for the player using them. Torrential Tribute can be used without destroying Super Dora since it can be chained with it's own effect to be immune to Torrential's fieldwipe. Overall, the gameplan of this deck is to force out a grindgame with a towers monster (Super Dora) and win in a battle of attrition with Fortress. All of this is accomplished with oppressive floodgates which block your opponent's play, while methodically picking them apart with high impact trap cards. Common Charity is a breathe of fresh air in the face of Yugioh's often stale meta, I encourage duelists to try it out! It's honestly the most fun I've had in Yugioh in a while!

deck_excerpt: Cyber Dragons, specifically tailored for Common Charity. Hit with BIG NUMBER and OTK!
deck_description: A deck specifically made for the "Common Charity" format that is officially supported by Konami. This format only uses cards that come in the common rarity. Here is a bit of a simpler deck explanation as opposed to my 2000 word+ articles. I'm gonna pump out quite a bit of Common Charity guides in the near future for the sake of this young and exciting format! This list is an almost identical list of the Duelist Bombderday who achieved a top 8 in the "Common Charity 2" out of 64 players. Forced to only use common cards, Cyber Dragon loses key combo pieces like Galaxy Soldier and Cyber Herz. Not only that, Cyber Dragon loses its main boss monster, Cyber Dragon Infinity. With It's signature control card out of the format, Cyber Dragons only have one option - HIT WITH BIG NUMBER. This deck aims to go second, opting to completely obliterate the opponent's lifepoints after breaking their board/backrow. Currently the meta in Common Charity consists of a lot of potent backrow like Solemns, Torrential Tribute, Compulse, etc. so x3 Hey! Trunade serves as this deck's backrow removal. Chimeratech Rampage Dragon also destroys backrow with it's on-summon ability. Monster board breakers in this deck consist ofÂ  Jizukiru (searcheable off of Cyber Repair Plant) and x3 Forbidden Chalice. Combos with this deck are hand dependent, simple and straightforward, but the goal is always the same - summon lots of Cyber Dragons after breaking your opponent's board and OTK. Hands with Cyber Emergency/Cyber Dragon Core + Machine Duplication are essentially full combo. The Extra Deck features the standard Cyber Dragon monsters, except without Infinity. The only unusual monster is Barbaroid, the Ultimate Battle Machine, which is summonable if your Cyber Dragon Nova gets sent to the GY. This deck doesn't really do well in a grindgame, so make sure to destroy your opponent's lifepoints quickly and efficiently before they bounce back and force you in a unpleasant losing situation. Common Charity is a breathe of fresh air in the face of Yugioh's often stale meta, I encourage duelists to try it out! It's honestly the most fun I've had in Yugioh in a while!

Currently, Zefra is in an utterly unplayable state and physically cannot win games without relying on several busted-ass crutches to accomplish anything. Konami, make Pendulums great again.   Halqifibrax Combo: The main goal of this deck is to turbo out Crystron Halqifibrax and go into an Auroradon combo to set up at least 3 negates, taking so much time doing the combo that your opponent would wish they'd never entered your lobby. For those that know the combo, don't even bother reading anything listed below, and for those that for some God-forsaken reason have no clue how to do the Halq combo, you'd better get comfortable, because you're about to read some real bullshit.
  1. Summon the materials needed forÂ Crystron Halqifibrax. This is done by usingÂ Zefraxi, Treasure of the Yang Zing which has the effect that when Pend Summoned, it can turn anyÂ Zefra monster you control into a tuner. The best monster to summon alongside Zefraxi isÂ Zefraniu, Secret of the Yang Zing, off which you will searchÂ Zefra War for an additional interruption. If you'reÂ desperate, normal summoning a handtrap is a completely viable option.Â Do not summon more than 2 monsters onto the board as all zones will be used during this combo.
  2. Activate Halq, summoningÂ Deskbot 001
  3. Using Halq and 001, link summonÂ Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon, and activate its effect to summon 3 tokens. Activate Deskbot 001.
  4. Using 001 and a token, summonÂ Cupid Pitch. Activate Cupid's effect and choose to gain a level.
  5. ActivateÂ Auroradon, choosing his second effect to tribute two tokens and summonÂ Mecha Phantom Beast Coltwing from your deck. Activate Coltwing to summon 2 tokens alongside 001.
  6. You must do the following steps in order or you'll mess up the combo, and look like a complete idiot in front of your opponent. Using your L5 Cupid Pitch and a Token, summon Borreload Savage Dragon. I've personally seen it happen, so I'll remind you right now to activate Borreload Savage Dragon and equip Halqifibrax.
  7. Activate Cupid Pitch from the graveyard, searchingÂ Creation Resonator,Â and immediately Special Summon it from hand (Borrelsavage is a L8 DARK Dragon).
  8. Using Creation Resonator and Coltwing, summonÂ Baronne de Fleur.
  9. SummonÂ Herald of the Arc Light using a token and 001.
  10. Watch Opponent scoop, effectively having made you play solitaire.
Oh no! What if Halqifibrax is negated??? Halqifibrax is the most fucking telegraphed chokepoint in the world, and your opponent might need to get checked if they don't shotgun the Ash or Imperm on it. This is whereÂ Crossout DesignatorÂ comes in. If you did not draw Crossout, remain calm and follow these steps:
  • In most scenarios, you do not expend your Normal Summon. In this case, simply normal summon a monster from your hand and summon Verte to makeÂ Destiny Hero - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer.
  • If you hard drawÂ Fusion Destiny, just hard activate it and make DPE.
  • If neither option is available to you, these following options are still open:
    • Set Zefra War and pray to God a single pop is enough to stop your opponent.
    • Draw enough handtraps to hopefully hamper your opponent.
    • Apologise to Trif for playing this abomination.
    • Scoop.
    • Just draw Fusion Destiny 5head.
Actual Zefra Stuff If you draw a hand that physically cannot go into Halqifibrax, and you deem that Verte is not the right play, your next best card is Zefraniu, Secret of the Yang Zing. It deadass searches your entire deck upon Pend Summon or destruction (if you need a Zefra monster, add Zefra Providence or Oracle of Zefra). Generally, if you need to squeeze as many interactions out of Zefraniu as possible, addÂ Nine Pillars of the Yang Zing, and when Zefraniu is destroyed during the next turn from Nine Pillars, you addÂ Zefra War (this card can be used from hand if you have Zefras in both pend zones). Whatever you do, don't actually summonÂ ZefraathÂ from your face-up Extra Deck. After the Great Pendulum Purge of MR4, this card has becomeÂ dogshit useless. As it summons from your Extra-Deck, it must go into a Linked Zone, and the fucker tributes theÂ entire field,Â leaving the only available zone the Extra Monster Zone. This means that you literally cannot use its second effect that grants a second Pendulum Summon each turn, making it little more than a fat body. The only exception is when your Opponent has a link arrow that points into one of your zones. The remainder of the Zefra monster lineup is entirely down to personal preference. You can even replace Zefracore and Zefrathuban with other generic cards if you were insane enough.   Mildly-to-Extremely Questionable Picks Zefra Metaltron: He is literally here for flavor points. There is probably a better monster to play over Metaltron for the link arrows. Hell, even Draco Master of the Tenyi is probably better... Number 41: Bagooska the Terribly Tired Tapir: This is a flex spot. You can literally play whatever the hell you want here. I just like Bagooska as it induces copious amounts of salt. If you are playing against a deck thatÂ does get utterly cucked by this floodgate, you can side it in and search it off Zefraniu.   Terrible Ideas to Consider: Here are some (probably) absolutely awful ideas to try out if you're trying to actively make your deck worse. In the case that you don't play Halqifibrax on turn 1, you can summon Halq, pulling anÂ Effect Veiler from your deck. From there, you summon Selene, use Selene's effect to revive the Veiler and make an Accesscode, I guess. Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon: After being Semi-Limited, Dragoon may actually be a decent consideration over DPE. However, there is still a decent probability of hard drawing the Fusion Destiny, so it's really your call at this point. My old HalqÂ Combo: Replace Baronne de Fleur withÂ Ravenous Crocodragon Arcethys, slot in a Metaphys Horus in the ED, and replace Creation Resonator with Hop Ear Squadron. My old guide covers this combo, but I'll just paste it here:
  1. Get a monster and a tuner on board, and only those 2 monsters. Resist the urge to pendulum summon everything out of hand. If you're desperate, the handtraps are tuners.
  2. SummonÂ Crystron Halqifibrax, activate its trigger effect to summonÂ Deskbot 001Â from deck.
  3. Link forÂ Mecha-Phantom Beast Auroradon, summon 3 tokens, then summon 001 from GY.

The BRANDED cards in the Main Deck consist of 13 cards: 1 Aluber the Jester of Despia, 2 Fallen of Albaz, 3 Springans Kitt, 3 Incredible Ecclesia, and 1 Iris Swordsoul, 3 Branded Fusion. In the Extra Deck there are 3 Albion, 2 Lubellion, and 2 Mirrorjade. 1 Starving Venom and 1 Titaniklad serve as additional âsuperpolyâ targets for Albaz. The SHADOLL cards are a minor package in this deck, consisting only of 2 cards: Winda and Qashaddol Keios. The STAPLE cards in this deck take up 10 slots in this deck. 3 Allure of Darkness serve as draw power, and 6 handtraps 3 Impermanence and 3 Dimension Shifter. 1 Called By the Grave provides protection from handtraps and a potential disruption for the opponent. I chose to make the staples in this decklist affordable, but they can be replaced by more potent (and expensive) cards like Lightning Storm and Forbidden Droplet. COMBOS AND GAMEPLAN The GAMEPLAN with this deck is simple â control the board going first, and OTK going second. If the game manages to lasts several turns, both Branded and Thunder Dragon cards recycle themselves and provide sizeable resources. At the end of every turn, Incredible Ecclesia recycles herself + Albion grabs you another Branded Fusion from deck. Thunder Dragon Fusion can also be banished the turn after you use it to allow you to search for Thunder Dragonroar, which can be discarded to recover Thunder Dragon Fusion from the banished pile. Since these two archetypes recur almost indefinitely, you should be able to outgrind your opponent in resource war. GOING FIRST, boards that end on Thunder Dragon Titanâs destruction and Windaâs floodgate are often enough to pressure your opponentâs gameplan to a standstill. Simply use Branded Fusion to dump to the GY the light Shadoll monster Keios to fuse into Albion, then use Albionâs effect to make Winda! Keep in mind you only have one summon to make after making Winda, so be sure to combo off properly making Thunder Dragon Titan first, then making Winda afterward. GOING SECOND, boards are easily picked apart by Thunder Dragonâs multiple pops and Mirrorjadeâs banish. Incredible Ecclesia works together with her bestie, Fallen of Albaz to âsuperpolyâ away your opponentâs problematic monsters. All of this often accomplished without using your normal summon! After breaking an opponentâs board, this deck can easily generate enough gigantic monsters onboard to obliterate your opponentâs lifepoints in one turn. COMBOS with this deck simple but take practice to fully master. Combos are typically hand-dependent, but end with a board full of Thunder Dragon and Branded fusion monsters. In addition to the combos featured earlier, here are some examples of additional combos: Thunder Dragon + Ready Fusion: Activate Ready Fusion to summon Kaminari Attack, then special summon Thunder Dragon Titan by banishing Kaminari Attack and your Thunder Dragon in hand. It is ideal to banish Thunder Dragondark for this effect, since banishing it allows you to search for an essential Thunder Dragon combo piece like ammunition for Thunder Dragon Titan or Thunder Dragon Fusion. Albion effect Â + Thunder Dragondark in GY = Search Thunder Dragon card: If Thunder Dragondark is already in the GY, Albion can banish Thunder Dragondark to create Lubellion. Doing so will trigger Dragondarkâs effect to search for any Thunderdragon card that youâre mission. Ready Fusion + Branded Fusion = Mirrorjade: After using Ready Fusion to create Thunder Dragon Titan, a Kaminari Attack should be in the banished pile. The Branded Fusion combo line (Albion -> Lubellion -> Mirrorjade) can use Kaminari Attack in the banished pile as one of the materials to fuse Mirrorjade, without using up one of your Branded Dragons already on the field! There are more situational combos that a pilot can do with this deck, but itâs largely dependent on the game state, cards in hand, and what the opponent has. Thatâs why itâs crucial to practice this deck so one can optimize play. Iâd describe Branded Thunder Dragon as easy to play, but hard to master. GENERAL TIPS
  • Ideally, this deck can feature monsters like Dragoon, Blue Eyes Tyrant Dragon and Invoked Mechaba! All you have to do is use another garnet in your deck, The Light -Hex-Sealed Fusion, dumped off Branded Fusion for the summon of Albion. Albion then makes your fusion of choice, using Hex-Sealedâs fusion substitution ability!
  • Your hand going second will likely have ways to fuse into your Branded and Thunder Dragon monsters, but try to bait/break your opponentâs interruption first before heading into your main plays.
  • If you want to focus more on destroying multiple backrow, creating Thunder Dragon Titan is the ideal play, since it can pop cards on the field multiple times without targeting and can survive being destroyed multiple times (for ex. Torrential Tribute or Conquistador of the Golden Land).
  • Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer fits comfortably in this deck, but the inclusion of other cards in Branded Thunder Dragon reduces consistency, lessens access to boardbreakers, etc. If you can put this guy in your deck, I highly recommend it!
  • Since this deck lacks an inherent normal summons and doesnât really set cards, Denko Sekka can be sidedeck option for backrow heavy games. She is also searchable off Thunder Dragon Fusion!
  • Chaos cards/chaos engine function wonderfully with this deck. If youâre willing to let go of staples or increase your decksize beyond 40, I recommend fitting Chaos Space, Chaos Dragon Levianeer, Chaos Creator (searchable off Thunder Dragon Fusion), Chaos Valkyria, etc.
  • This deck is particularly weak to backrow, floodgates and high impact handtraps. Be sure to side properly to counter your opponents!
  • When siding with this deck in-between games, the cards able to be switched the most are the 3 Allure of Darkness (sacrificing consistency), the 3 Dimension Shifter, and the Ecclesia cards (3 Incredible Ecclesia, 1 Iris Swordsoul). Replace these 10 cards with whatever you like going first or second!
  • Dimension Shifter works incredibly well with this deck. Careful of using this card since it cuts off some combo lines for both Thunder Dragon and Branded!
  • The Branded Albaz and Lubellion require a discard for their cost, and Thunder Dragons provide ample fodder for discards. Dragondark especially loves being in the GY, since it can potentially be banished by Albionâs effect, triggering Dragondarkâs search effect.
  • Verte Anaconda can be used should you lack access to either Branded or Thunder Dragon fusion. Just keep in mind you canât summon Verte the same turn you used Branded Fusion since youâre locked into fusion extra deck monsters for the rest of the turn.
  • Lubellion can recycle any monster cards used for its fusion effect in the GY or banished pile, including Thunder Dragon monsters. Keep this in mind if youâre running out of particular cards in your maindeck/extra deck!
CONCLUDING COMMENTARY The synergy between these decks almost seem like these two archetypes were designed to support each other! For example, Branded Fusion mills Thunder Dragons to the GY, Albion banishes Thunder Dragons in the GY to fuse while triggering their effects, Mirrorjade recycles Extra Deck monsters in the banished pile, Thunder Dragons maintain hand advantage serving as discard fodder for Branded cardsâ¦ The synergies between these two are incredible! Iâve enjoyed the simple control/beatdown strategy of Thunder Dragons for years, combining it with multiple different variants such as Chaos and Rokket to propel this deck forward. With their new bestie Albaz and friends, Thunder Dragons gains an entirely new dimension of power and playability! Who knows, maybe in the future Thunder Dragons may reclaim itâs mantle of tier 1 meta deck once more! Just please donât unleash Thunder Dragon Colossus again Konami, that card was ridiculous.

I couldn't think of a name or reference to make, so here's just a typical Despia Albaz deck, featuring their newest trap card, Branded Exile. There's only 1 copy of Exile, so you can still go second, but it's better to go first most of the time.

It is here~ The Cyber Strike Structure deck is here and it turned out to be even more fun than I expected it to be. (Still, Rip Lightning Storm ;_;) But even without the inclusion of a reprint for Lightning Storm, we still got amazing reprints with it, which makes it absolutely worth buying a pack of 3 of this awesome SD. Cards like "Fusion Deployment", "Cyber Dragon Herz" and the infamous "Infinite Impermanence". But reprints aren't everything this SD has to offer. New cards like "Cyber Eternal" or the Cyberdark archetypes newest Boss Monster "Cyberdark End Dragon" are also included and give the deck a huge power boost. Anyway, I'm not going to waste more time, let's get right into the deck profile. Be careful tho, this'll get edgy. VERY edgy. Seriously. Let's start with the basics. This deck is really not depending on going 1st or going 2nd. You usually got something for both cases, altho going 2nd is a bit favored, due to the deck consisting of roughly 60% Cyberdark and 40% Cyberdragon, which is usually a going 2nd deck. Anyway, what to do if you are forced to go 1st? In this scary moment you usually wanna go straight into your biggest and strongest Beast of them all: The "Cyberdark End Dragon". This will most of the time; depending on how your starting hand looks; cost you a good bunch of resources as well as a LP amount of 2000 and will leave you with; again depending on your starting hand; the Dragon and maybe one or two more cards in form of backrow. All you need to get the Emperor Dragon out, is at least one copy of any Trap- or Spell-Card and the new (searchable) Spell-Card "Cybernetic Horizon". The rest will be searchable in around 18 out of 20 cases if you don't already have it. What you gonna do is get at least 5 Cyberdark Monsters (No matter which ones) in your GY, your hand or on the field (not as equip spells!), one of them being on the field is the new Cyberdark Monster "Cyberdark Chimera". This can be easily done by using the Cybernetic Horizon spell. Make sure to send "Cyber End Dragon" from your Extra-Deck to the GY when using Horizon. Tipp: If somehow one Cyberdark monster is missing, you can also send your second Cyberdark Chimera from your deck to the graveyard to send another Cyberdark to your graveyard by using Chimeras second effect. Now use Chimeras first effect, discard the before mentioned random backrow card and search "Power Bond". Use Power Bond to Fusion summon "Cyberdarkness Dragon" by using the 5 Cyberdarks in your hand, field or by banishing them from the graveyard, which is possible thanks to Chimeras effect. Uppon summoning Cyberdarkness Dragon, use it's effect to equip Cyber End Dragon to it and then tribute it to summon your Cyberdark End Dragon. As a second option, you can also keep your 8000 ATK Cyberdarkness Dragon. Good thing about that is, that you have an omni negate for every equip card on the field. Even if there aren't any, you can use Cyber End Dragon as well, on cost of putting Cyberdarkness' ATK down to "just" 4000. I however, as the going first option, mostly chose to go into the Cyberdark End Dragon, since 5000 ATK combined with being completely unaffected by any activated effects from your opponent is just too good. Just keep in mind, that it won't protect it from Kaiju-like effects as well as from permanent effects or "passive" effects like Skill Drain. It is however protected from Super Polymerisation since it has to be activated before actually using something as Fusion material. Another good side note is that you can revive Cyberdarkness Dragon after tributing it via "Cyber Eternal", getting your omni negate back; this time with "just" 6000 ATK but still; if you manage to have it in your hand or search it via "Cyber Dragon Core". It's a very good combination with the Cyberdark End Dragon by the way, since it can constantly grab 'n' equip monsters from both graveyards, giving your Cyberdarkness Dragon more negates and gives you the possibility to pull out important monsters from your opponents graveyard interupting their plays, like Doomking Balerdroch to just name one. So that's everything for the going first part. The going second part is actually much shorter, I promise. In this section I talk about some basic and advanced combos since the going second part is literally the whole first part if you wanna sweat a bit or just everything else the deck has to offer. The deck focuses on literally everything that makes Cyberdark for me: Effectiveness (seriously, don't play this deck against somebody who's only out for fun and casual play, this will come of as a bit unfair), Feeling (Simping for Zane/Ryo) and semi-fun/casual play. That's why I play the deck in it's in my eyes best form, combined with Cyberdragons in the best Zane-manner. You main strategies are of course using the main Cyberdark's being "Cyberdark Horn", "Cyberdark Edge" and "Cyberdark Keel". Combined with the main searchers of the deck as well as main equip monsters "Cyberdark Cannon" and "Cyberdark Claw", they become 2400 ATK beatsticks with additional effects. Claw is your backrow searcher and Cannon is your monster searcher. Whilst equipped with to a monster, Claw that equips and battles can send a monster from the Extra-Deck to your GY which works perfectly with "Elder Entity N'tss" to pop a card of choice. Another good option is "Predaplant Chimerafflesia", which then let's you search any Fusion spell. Just keep in mind, that a Cyber Monster send to the GY by this or Horizon's effect, can't be revived by Cyber Eternal. It ignores summoning conditions, but only the ones that are one the card but not the ones that are in the games basic rules which need you to summon a Fusion Monster properly first before you are able to revive it by other means. Cannon however let's you send a Cyberdark monster from your Deck to your GY. You may wanna use this to get easier Fusion summons since you mostly use monsters in your graveyard as material. This for the basic playstyle. Now to some "advanced" combos. Starting with the whole selection of Cyberdragons. The Cyberdarks really go hand in hand with the original Cyberdragons (and even need them for Cybernetic Horizon) and you have a big pool to chose from. I go with the very core of the Cyberdragon engine being the normal set of 3Â Cyberdragons,Â Cyber Dragon Core for the search since it can search really every Cyberdragon and Cyberdark- Spell and Trap. Cyber Dragon Herz is a beautiful combo extender about which I will talk a bit more soon. Lastly "Cyber Dragon Drei". Another choice which is enough as a one-of due to reasons I talk about later on. As I said before, you need the Light Machine engine to get Cybernetic Horizon to work which is a very important card and they also go very well with the "Rush-Down-Beat-Down" tactic (short: RDBD™). The first important combo is the usual "Get-most-out-of-"-combo involving Cybernetic Horizon. The card requires you to send one of your Light and one of your Dark monsters to the GY. One from your hand and one from your Deck. It's important to send a Cyberdark monster from your hand to the graveyard to then send a Cyberdragon from your deck to the grave, which will be Cyber Dragon Herz. It's effect will activate and let you take one of the original Cyber Dragons to your hand. Right after that, you can take another "Cyber-" monster to your hand from your deck. You can really take everything that's name is "Cyber...", even the Malefic Cyber End Dragon or cards that aren't even Cyberdragon related, like Cyber Kirin. This will give you the maximum out of your Cybernetic Horizon spell. Lets head on to the next important piece which involves Cyber Dragon Drei. The sole purpose of this card in the deck is to add it to your hand and normal summon it to activate it's effect and make it's own Level become 5. Here again, by using Cybernetic Horizon, sending a Cyber Dragon Herz to the GY, you can add an additional default Cyber Dragon to your hand together with Cyber Dragon Drei. Summon it, then normal summon Cyber Dragon Drei to go into the Xyz-monster "Cyber Dragon Nova" and "Cyber Dragon Infinity". Infinity is an important monster removal and a strong omni negate. Next. A way to turn this deck into a true Suicide Bomb is via "Future Fusion". What's nice about this, is that it basicly comes just while playing the deck normally. You got plenty possibilities to send Chimerafflesia to the GY, to activate it's effect and search for Future Fusion. Activate it and in case it stays on the field until the next turn (Easy done when already having a Cyberdarkness Dragon out or a "Cyberdark Invasion" to prevent your opponent from destroying it), you can show your opponent your "Chimeratech Overdragon", dumb all Machine type monsters in your deck and then use Cyberdark Chimera's effect to get Powerbond and summon the Overdragon with your whole deck, creating a monster just with your Main Deck that can attack your opponents monsters up to 16 times, with 12800 ATK. If you use Power Bond, you got a monster with 25600 ATK. The only drawback is that you receive 12800 damage at the end of that turn, which will definetely kill you. So, pray that your attack with an enormous 25600 will hit it's target like a well-placed Predator Rocket. Cause if that won't work, you'll be dead by the end of your turn. ...unless you use Cyber Kirin for some reason- You can see, the target is clear. Deal huge amounts of battle damage to your opponent, until they lay in the dirt. OTK's won't be too rare. Good options if you try going for the OTK are the "Cyber Twin Dragon" and the "Chimeratech Rampagedragon". Make sure to use "Chimeratech Megafleet Dragon" to tribute problematic Link monsters from your opponent. "Rebirth Judgement" is not only one of Zane's cards, but a very good addition to the deck as well. You can use it to make your Cyberdark End Dragon more easy via "Cyberdark Dragon". You can also reuse N'tss by equiping it again to one of your Fusion monsters to trigger the destroy effect multiple times. You can also use it to steal important monsters from your opponents graveyard in combination with "Cyberdark Realm", which is also another searcher of yours. The deck is highly consistent and you will most likely never draw a dead hand. As for the Side Deck, there is quite a plethora of options you can go with. The classical "DNA Surgery" trick to tribute away every single monster your opponent controls for your "Chimeratech Fortress Dragon". Fusion Deployment to summon an easy Cyberdragon or "Limiter Removal" for more Suicide Bomb-Action. "Jizukiru, the Star Destroying Kaiju" is a beautiful option too since you can get rid of it easily by using Cyber Dragon Infinity's effect to take it back. Now, thank you for reading all the way trough this. If you like this Deck Recipe as well as my little guide to it, you can check out my other deck lists. For example my pure Cyberdragon Deck Absolute Cyber Might. Discord: Lucy💗🌺🦋#1508 Reddit Steam
